BLUE JAY ORCHESTRA WILL
BE FEATURED AT TEA
DANCE TOMORROW
Unique Affair Will Be A Tea Dance
With Tea; Is At Art
Centre
Making its first appearance of
the year, aside from Musical Club
concerts, the Blue Jay Orchestra
will play for a tea dance next Saturday at the Art Centre, 810 N.
Howard Street. A full twelvepiece orchestra of, Hopkins men
will be on hand for the affair, with
-Enoch Light directing. As an
added feature, Bob Van Horn will
sing.
The Blue Jays added greatly to
their reputation during the last
summer,--they were the attraction at Hendersonville, North

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 11, 1925.

TAU BETA PI TAKES
IN THREE INITIATES
Three men were publicly
initiated into the Tau Beta
Pi honorary engineering society yesterday at Assembly.
The men were Theodore M.
Graser, '26, Mechanical Engineer; David P. Shafer, '26,
Electrical Engineer; Robert
C. White, '27, Chemical Engineer.
Professor Albert Christie
read out the names of the
initiates and Mr. Abel Wolman delivered an address on
the aims of the society.
The new men were privately initiated at five o'clock
yesterday at the Southern
Hotel.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 11, 1925.

GREAT DOPE
Chairman Colt, of the June Week Committee, draws a deep
breath, braces himself, and announces that the 1926 June
Week will be an entirely local affair. Local orchestras will
furnish the music, the dances will be all held at Homewood,
and local talent will do much of the decorating and electrical
work. The NEWS-LETTER was scarcely prepared for such a
pleasant surprise, but it hastens to give the usual three cheers
for Chairman Colt and his committee. They obviously are the
stuff; they are responsible for great dope on June Week.
The mere fact that /the tickets will be cheaper is n.olt
responsible for all of our applause. Not at all; not at all.
The largest share goes to a June Week Committee with level
heads,—a committee that does not want to splurge for the sake
of spending, but which abandons such ribald plans for more
conservative and more sensible ones.
We little expected to see such a transformation in our
times, but, as long as it has been made, we are willing to risk
a free ticket to the whole affair that everyone will have as fine
a time as if the committee had spent thousands more than the
customary sum.
Hooray for the June Week Committee!

END THE SUSPENSE
While Dr. Goodnow continues to urge the adoption of his
two-year plan upon the Board of Trustees, that august body of
conservative Americans does not hasten to make a decision
upon the question. It considers, it weighs results in the balance, and, we believe, is awaiting assured financial support
before committing itself. We are of the opinion that the Trustees favor the plan, but in order to appear to act in their usual
conservative manner, do not hasten to put themselves on record
one way or the other.
Now the NEWS-LETTER, for reasons which it considers to be
good and sufficient, and which Editor Hiss let loose upon an
appalled world last Spring, is decidedly in favor of the New
, Plan. But we want to know what the future status of the
University will be. We wait with bated breath; we anxiously
scan every bulletin for some signs of action; we pant with the
eager expectation of a decision; we pray for the Trustees every
night. Is the New Plan going through, or will the present
-undergraduate school remain?
There has been ample time for the Trustees to scan every
:side of the problem; there have been sufficient days, weeks, and
months for them to act in a manner conservative enough to
satisfy the requirements of even the Maryland Club ,—so we
are hinting gracefully and gently that the world awaits their
decision. End the suspense.
However, we are willing to bet our best hat that there will
be no word until February 22. At that time Dr. Goodnow will
arise to make the customary announcements and will say that
future. Does anythe plan will be put into effect in the near'
one want to take our wager?

The NEWS-LETTER is pleased -to announce the election of
Richard R. Griffith, '28, and Morton Hamburger, Jr., '28, to
the position of Associate Editor; Cornelius S. Franckle, Jr.,
'28, George E. Banks, '29, Leonard B. Nolley, '29, and Robert
S. Nyburg, '29, to the position of Junior Editor • and Samuel
Hecht,'29, to the position of Assistant Business Manager.
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of
Arthur Swanson, '27, from the position of Assistant Business
Manager.

Following the lead of Johns
Hopkins University, Union College held a collegiate auto race.
Posters read "Kollege Kans in
Kross Kountry Kontest." The
machines raced against a sealed
time of 33 minutes for an eighthmile course over hill and dale. The
fastest time did not win but the
'time that came closest to 33 minutes. Twenty boilers entered and
there were no restrictions as to
the method of propelling the car
around. Some broke all speed
laws while others were forced to
push their machines most of the
way. One car turned turtle on a
steep hill and was wrecked, no
one was injured however. The affair was run by the Press Club
and pictures were taken which
will be exhibited all over the count ry.

FONDA GOES TO WORLD
COURT CONFERENCE
AT PRINCETON
Aim

Of Convention To Crystallize
Student Opinion And To
Appeal To Coolidge

Bayard Fonda has been selected
to represent Johns Hopkins at the
National Collegiate World Court
Conference being held at Princeton on December 11 and 12. The
conference is under the sponsorship of the Princeton Senior Council.
This meeting is probably the
largest ever undertaken by a university with the aim of finding
some solution among college students of questions of national and
international importance. It is
the desire of the council to have
as many colleges represented as
possible. Delegates are expected
from nearly every college east of
the Mississippi and a few in the
West.
The main purposes of the council are outlined as follows:
1. To crystallize student opinion of the entire country on the
World Court, with the subsequent
presentation of a resolution to
President Coolidge.
2. To inaugurate a permanent
organization of which the purpose
will be the formation of enlightenment and militant student opinion on all questions of national
and international importance.

TAU BETA PI TAKES
IN THREE INITIATES
Three men were publicly
initiated into the Tau Beta
Pi honorary engineering society yesterday at Assembly.
The men were Theodore M.
Graser, '26, Mechanical Engineer; David P. Shafer, '26,
Electrical Engineer; Robert
C. White, '27, Chemical Engineer.
Professor Albert Christie
read out the names of the
initiates and Mr. Abel Wolman delivered an address on
the aims of the society.
The new men were privately initiated at five o'clock
yesterday at the Southern
Hotel.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 11, 1925.

GREAT DOPE
Chairman Colt, of the June Week Committee, draws a deep
breath, braces himself, and announces that the 1926 June
Week will be an entirely local affair. Local orchestras will
furnish the music, the dances will be all held at Homewood,
and local talent will do much of the decorating and electrical
work. The NEWS-LETTER was scarcely prepared for such a
pleasant surprise, but it hastens to give the usual three cheers
for Chairman Colt and his committee. They obviously are the
stuff; they are responsible for great dope on June Week.
The mere fact that /the tickets will be cheaper is n.olt
responsible for all of our applause. Not at all; not at all.
The largest share goes to a June Week Committee with level
heads,—a committee that does not want to splurge for the sake
of spending, but which abandons such ribald plans for more
conservative and more sensible ones.
We little expected to see such a transformation in our
times, but, as long as it has been made, we are willing to risk
a free ticket to the whole affair that everyone will have as fine
a time as if the committee had spent thousands more than the
customary sum.
Hooray for the June Week Committee!

END THE SUSPENSE
While Dr. Goodnow continues to urge the adoption of his
two-year plan upon the Board of Trustees, that august body of
conservative Americans does not hasten to make a decision
upon the question. It considers, it weighs results in the balance, and, we believe, is awaiting assured financial support
before committing itself. We are of the opinion that the Trustees favor the plan, but in order to appear to act in their usual
conservative manner, do not hasten to put themselves on record
one way or the other.
Now the NEWS-LETTER, for reasons which it considers to be
good and sufficient, and which Editor Hiss let loose upon an
appalled world last Spring, is decidedly in favor of the New
, Plan. But we want to know what the future status of the
University will be. We wait with bated breath; we anxiously
scan every bulletin for some signs of action; we pant with the
eager expectation of a decision; we pray for the Trustees every
night. Is the New Plan going through, or will the present
-undergraduate school remain?
There has been ample time for the Trustees to scan every
:side of the problem; there have been sufficient days, weeks, and
months for them to act in a manner conservative enough to
satisfy the requirements of even the Maryland Club ,—so we

Following the lead of Johns
Hopkins University, Union College held a collegiate auto race.
Posters read "Kollege Kans in
Kross Kountry Kontest." The
machines raced against a sealed
time of 33 minutes for an eighthmile course over hill and dale. The
fastest time did not win but the
'time that came closest to 33 minutes. Twenty boilers entered and
there were no restrictions as to
the method of propelling the car
around. Some broke all speed
laws while others were forced to
push their machines most of the
way. One car turned turtle on a
steep hill and was wrecked, no
one was injured however. The affair was run by the Press Club
and pictures were taken which
will be exhibited all over the count ry.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 11, 1925

4
FONDA GOES TO WORLD
COURT CONFERENCE
AT PRINCETON
Aim

Of Convention To Crystallize
Student Opinion And To
Appeal To Coolidge

Bayard Fonda has been selected
to represent Johns Hopkins at the
National Collegiate World Court
Conference being held at Princeton on December 11 and 12. The
conference is under the sponsorship of the Princeton Senior Council.
This meeting is probably the
largest ever undertaken by a university with the aim of finding
some solution among college students of questions of national and
international importance. It is
the desire of the council to have
as many colleges represented as
possible. Delegates are expected
from nearly every college east of
the Mississippi and a few in the
West.
The main purposes of the council are outlined as follows:
1. To crystallize student opinion of the entire country on the
World Court, with the subsequent
presentation of a resolution to
President Coolidge.
2. To inaugurate a permanent
organization of which the purpose
will be the formation of enlightenment and militant student opinion on all questions of national
and international importance.

"The Lives Of Children" Deals With
Work Carried On By Harriet
Lane Home

The .Lives of Children, a review
of the accomplishments and needs
of The Harriet Lane Home for
Children, is the title of one of a
series of pamphlets issued by The
Half-Century Committee.
The
booklet is divided into three sections—The Gift of Fifty Years;
The Harriet Lane Home, and The
Hospitals Problem.
The first section deals with
what has been done in lengthening the lives of children. It tells
how cures have been found for ten
serious diseases and what is still
to be done. The second part deals
with the Home itself, and tells of
its laboratories, wards, private
rooms, and wards for communicable diseases. There are one
